action.action-desc: Mr. Carter of Georgia (for himself and Ms. Sewell) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a special rule for certain casualty losses of uncut timber.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Disaster Reforestation Act.

subsection.text: Section 165(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking For purposes of subsection (a) and inserting the following:
by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.header: Special rule for casualty loss of uncut timber

subparagraph.text: In the case of the loss of any uncut timber from fire, storm, or other casualty, or from theft, the basis for determining the amount of the deduction for such loss (as otherwise determined under paragraph (1)) shall not be less than the excess of—

clause.text: the appraised value of such uncut timber determined immediately before such loss was sustained, over
the salvage value of such timber.
With respect to the appraisal of a timber casualty loss described in subparagraph (A)—

subclause.text: the appraisal valuation date shall be not later than 1 year after the casualty loss, and

item.text: conform to the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice (USPAP),
be limited to the value of the lost timber, and
be completed by a Federal- or State-certified appraiser.

subclause.text: In the case of any taxpayer who is unable to obtain an appraisal described in clause (i) before the due date of the return of tax (including any extension of time for filing such return) for the taxable year in which the timber casualty loss occurred, the taxpayer may elect to—

item.text: with respect to the return of tax for such taxable year, include an estimate of the value of the uncut timber determined immediately before the loss was sustained, and

upon completion of the appraisal within the period described in clause (i)(I), file an amended return for such taxable year with respect to any adjustment in taxable income as determined pursuant to subclause (II).

subclause.text: With respect to any taxpayer who elects to provide an estimate described in subclause (I)(aa) for any taxable year in which a timber casualty loss occurred, the taxable income of the taxpayer for such taxable year shall be increased or decreased, as applicable, by an amount equal to the difference between—

item.text: the appraised value of such uncut timber determined immediately before such loss was sustained, as determined pursuant to the appraisal described in clause (i), and
the estimate provided by the taxpayer under subclause (I)(aa) with respect to such uncut timber.

subparagraph.header: Exclusion of timber not held for sale
subparagraph.text: Subparagraph (A) shall not apply to any timber unless such timber is held for the purpose of being cut and sold in connection with a trade or business that is not a passive activity within the meaning of section 469.
For purposes of this paragraph, the term uncut timber shall not fail to include pre-merchantable timber.

clause.text: Subparagraph (A) shall not apply unless the uncut timber subject to the loss is reforested (with hardwoods, softwoods, or any combination thereof) by planting, seeding, or appropriate site preparation, not later than the close of the 5-year period beginning on the date of such loss.

The Secretary shall, by regulations, provide for recapturing the benefit of any deduction allowed under this section with respect to any uncut timber subject to loss to which subparagraph (A) applied if the taxpayer fails to comply with clause (i) during the period provided under such clause.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to losses sustained in taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.
